modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Adjacency

Pure PureScript adjacency matrix layout algorithm.

An adjacency matrix is a square grid where:
- Each row and column represents a node
- Each cell (i,j) represents the connection from node i to node j
- Non-zero values indicate connections, zero indicates no connection

This module provides pure layout computation that can be used with
any rendering backend (D3, Canvas, SVG, etc.)

Example usage:
```purescript
let matrix = { matrix: [[0,1,0],[1,0,1],[0,1,0]], names: ["A","B","C"] }
    layoutResult = layout matrix
-- layoutResult.cells contains positioned cells ready for rendering
```

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Chord

Pure PureScript chord diagram layout algorithm.

A chord diagram shows relationships between nodes arranged in a circle,
with ribbons (curved bands) connecting related nodes.

This module provides pure layout computation that can be used with
any rendering backend (Hylograph HATS, D3, Canvas, SVG, etc.)

Example usage:
```purescript
import DataViz.Layout.Chord (layout)

let matrix = [[0,1,2],[1,0,3],[2,3,0]]
    result = layout matrix
-- result.groups contains arc positions
-- result.chords contains ribbon connections
```

For rendering, use the path generators in Hylograph.Expr.Path.Generators:
- `genArc` for the arc segments
- `genRibbon` for the ribbon paths

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Chord.Layout

Pure PureScript implementation of the chord layout algorithm.

The algorithm:
1. Compute row sums to get total value for each group
2. Compute the grand total of all values
3. Assign angular extent to each group proportional to its value
4. For each non-zero matrix[i][j], create a chord connecting groups
5. Track angular position within each group for ribbon placement

declarations.comments: Layout a chord diagram with default configuration
declarations.title: layout

declarations.comments: Layout a chord diagram with custom configuration
declarations.title: layoutWithConfig

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Chord.Layout

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Chord.Types

Types for chord diagram visualization.

A chord diagram shows relationships between nodes arranged in a circle,
with ribbons (curved bands) connecting related nodes.

The layout takes a square matrix where:
- matrix[i][j] represents the flow/connection strength from node i to node j
- Each node gets an arc proportional to its total connections
- Ribbons connect arcs, with width proportional to connection strength

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.Cluster

Cluster (dendrogram) layout using Data.Tree
Uses Reingold-Tilford algorithm for x-positioning (like Tree)
But positions nodes by height (distance from leaves) instead of depth
Result: All leaf nodes appear at the same level (y = 0)

declarations.comments: Configuration for cluster layout
declarations.title: ClusterConfig

declarations.comments: Default configuration
declarations.title: defaultClusterConfig

declarations.comments:
Cluster layout in 4 steps:
1. addHeight: Bottom-up pass computing height (distance from deepest leaf)
2. sortByHeight: Sort children by height to minimize crossovers (D3 pattern)
3. render: Bottom-up pass assigning sequential x to leaves, mean x to parents
4. addY: Add y coordinates based on height (leaves at 0)
5. scale: Scale abstract coordinates to pixel coordinates

Key difference from Tree:
- All leaves get sequential x positions (not contour-based)
- y is based on height (distance from leaves) not depth
- All leaves appear at y = 0 (dendrogram)
- Children sorted by height (descending) to minimize crossovers

Input must have x, y, height fields (initial values don't matter, they'll be overwritten)
declarations.title: cluster

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.Cluster

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.Core

Pure PureScript implementation of D3 hierarchy core functions.
Matches D3's algorithms exactly but using pure functional style.

declarations.comments:
Construct a hierarchy from user data
Matches D3's hierarchy() function

Simplified implementation using recursion instead of D3's iterative approach
This is more idiomatic for PureScript while producing identical results
declarations.title: hierarchy

declarations.comments:
Compute aggregate values bottom-up
Matches D3's .sum() method

Formula: node.value = value(node.data) + (child.value)
declarations.title: sum

declarations.comments:
Count descendants
Matches D3's .count() method

Formula:
- Leaf: value = 1
- Internal: value = (child.value)
declarations.title: count

declarations.comments:
Pre-order traversal (visit parent before children)
Matches D3's .eachBefore() method

Order: root  A  A1  A2  B  B1  B2
declarations.title: eachBefore

declarations.comments:
Post-order traversal (visit children before parent)
Matches D3's .eachAfter() method

Order: A1  A2  A  B1  B2  B  root
declarations.title: eachAfter

declarations.comments:
Get all descendant nodes (including self)
Matches D3's .descendants() method
declarations.title: descendants

declarations.comments:
Get all leaf nodes (nodes with no children)
Matches D3's .leaves() method
declarations.title: leaves

declarations.comments:
Sort children by comparator
Matches D3's .sort() method

Note: This returns a new hierarchy (pure function)
declarations.title: sortHierarchy

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.Core

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.EdgeBundle

Hierarchical edge bundling layout for visualizing dependencies in hierarchical data.

Based on Danny Holten's algorithm:
"Hierarchical Edge Bundles: Visualization of Adjacency Relations in Hierarchical Data"

This module provides:
- Hierarchy construction from flat dot-notation names
- Bidirectional link creation (bilink)
- Radial cluster layout for node positioning
- Bundle curve rendering with adjustable tension (beta)

## Example Usage:

```purescript
import DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.EdgeBundle as EdgeBundle

-- Given flat data with imports
nodes :: Array { name :: String, size :: Number, imports :: Array String }

-- Build the visualization
result = EdgeBundle.edgeBundle
  { getName: _.name
  , getImports: _.imports
  , beta: 0.85
  , radius: 400.0
  }
  nodes

-- result contains:
--   nodes: positioned nodes for rendering
--   links: paths between connected nodes
```

declarations.comments:
Main entry point: compute edge bundle layout

Takes configuration and array of nodes with imports,
returns positioned nodes and bundled link paths.
declarations.title: edgeBundle

declarations.title: EdgeBundleResult

declarations.title: PositionedNode

declarations.comments: A bundled link with SVG path
declarations.title: BundledLink

Create bidirectional links from a hierarchy and import data

Algorithm:
1. Build a map from fullName -> leaf node
2. For each leaf with imports, create outgoing links
3. For each outgoing link, add corresponding incoming link to target

Takes:
- A tree built from buildHierarchy
- A function to get imports from the leaf data

Uses quadratic Bezier spline approximation with bundle tension

The beta parameter controls tension:
- beta = 0: control points are not adjusted (straight-ish curve)
- beta = 1: control points follow the path exactly (maximum bundling)

Create bidirectional links between nodes based on imports.
This implements D3's bilink pattern:
- Each leaf node gets an "outgoing" array (imports it makes)
- Each leaf node gets an "incoming" array (nodes that import it)

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.EdgeBundle.BundleCurve

Bundle curve generator for hierarchical edge bundling.
Implements Danny Holten's algorithm with adjustable beta (tension) parameter.

The bundle curve draws a smooth B-spline through a path of ancestor nodes:
- beta = 0: straight line from source to target
- beta = 1: curve goes through all ancestor nodes
- beta = 0.85: D3's default, good balance of bundling and readability

declarations.comments:
Generate SVG path for a bundle curve given points
Uses quadratic Bezier spline approximation with bundle tension

The beta parameter controls tension:
- beta = 0: control points are not adjusted (straight-ish curve)
- beta = 1: control points follow the path exactly (maximum bundling)
declarations.title: bundlePath

declarations.comments:
Generate bundle path from radial coordinates
Takes (angle, radius) pairs and converts to Cartesian for rendering
declarations.title: bundlePathRadial

declarations.comments: Generate bundle path from Cartesian coordinates directly
declarations.title: bundlePathCartesian

declarations.comments: A point on the bundle path
declarations.title: BundlePoint

declarations.comments: Default beta (tension) value - D3's default
declarations.title: beta

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.EdgeBundle.RadialCluster

Radial cluster layout for edge bundling.
Positions leaf nodes around a circle and internal nodes at the center.

The layout uses (angle, radius) coordinates:
- angle: position around the circle (0 to 2 radians)
- radius: distance from center (internal nodes closer to center, leaves at edge)

declarations.comments: Configuration for radial cluster layout
declarations.title: RadialLayoutConfig

declarations.comments: Default configuration
declarations.title: defaultRadialConfig

declarations.comments: A node with radial coordinates
declarations.title: RadialNode

declarations.comments:
Apply radial cluster layout to a tree

Algorithm:
1. Assign sequential indices to leaves (angular positions)
2. Position leaves evenly around the circle at outerRadius
3. Position internal nodes at mean angle of children, at appropriate radius
declarations.title: radialCluster

declarations.comments: Convert radial coordinates to Cartesian for SVG rendering
declarations.title: toCartesian

declarations.comments: Convenience function: layout from a TreeNode using default config

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.EdgeBundle.Types

Types for hierarchical edge bundling visualization.
Based on Danny Holten's algorithm and D3's implementation.

Edge bundling shows dependencies between nodes in a hierarchy by:
1. Arranging nodes in a radial cluster layout
2. Drawing curved edges that bundle together based on shared ancestry
3. The tighter the bundle (higher beta), the more edges follow tree structure

declarations.comments:
Input format: flat array of nodes with dot-notation names and imports
Example: { "name": "flare.animate.Easing", "size": 17010, "imports": ["flare.util.Arrays"] }
declarations.title: ImportedNode

declarations.comments: Parse a Foreign value into an ImportedNode
declarations.title: parseImportedNode

declarations.title: BundleTree

A node in the bundle hierarchy tree
Contains the data plus computed layout information
declarations.title: BundleNode

declarations.title: getBundleData

declarations.comments: Get children of a bundle node
declarations.title: getBundleChildren

declarations.comments: Get parent of a bundle node
declarations.title: getBundleParent

A bundle link after path computation
Contains the path through the tree from source to target
declarations.title: BundleLink

declarations.comments:
An outgoing link (from source to target)
The link itself is a pair: [source, target]
declarations.title: OutgoingLink

declarations.comments: An incoming link (from source to this node as target)

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.EdgeBundle.Types

modules.comments:
SVG path generators for hierarchical tree links.

Provides multiple link styles for connecting parent-child nodes in tree layouts:

- **Step links**: Right-angle paths (H-V-H or V-H-V) for orthogonal trees
- **Bezier links**: Smooth cubic curves for organic-looking trees
- **Radial links**: Curved paths for radial/polar tree layouts
- **Diagonal links**: Simple straight lines

Each generator takes source and target coordinates and returns an SVG path string.
Use `linkGenerator` to dispatch based on `LinkStyle`.

declarations.comments: Link style for hierarchical layouts
declarations.title: LinkStyle

declarations.comments:
Generate SVG path for horizontal step link (H-V-H)
Good for left-to-right or right-to-left trees
declarations.title: linkStepHorizontal

declarations.comments:
Generate SVG path for vertical step link (V-H-V)
Good for top-to-bottom trees (dendrograms)
declarations.title: linkStepVertical

declarations.comments:
Generate SVG path for vertical bezier link
Good for aesthetic top-down tree diagrams
declarations.title: linkBezierVertical

declarations.comments:
Generate SVG path for horizontal bezier link
Good for aesthetic left-to-right tree diagrams
declarations.title: linkBezierHorizontal

declarations.comments:
Generate SVG path for radial bezier link
Converts Cartesian to polar coordinates for radial layouts
Input: source (x1, y1) and target (x2, y2) in tree coordinates
where x represents angle and y represents radius
declarations.title: linkBezierRadial

declarations.comments:
Generate SVG path for radial bezier link from Cartesian coordinates
Takes Cartesian (x, y) coordinates and converts to polar internally
to calculate proper radial control points.
Complements `linkBezierRadial` which takes angle/radius coordinates.
declarations.title: linkBezierRadialCartesian

declarations.comments: Generate SVG path for diagonal link (straight line)
declarations.title: linkDiagonal

declarations.comments: Get link generator function for a given style
declarations.title: linkGenerator

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.Link

modules.comments:
Circle packing layout algorithm.

Implements the front-chain circle packing algorithm for laying out hierarchical
data as nested circles. Each node's area is proportional to its value, with
children packed inside their parent's circle.

The algorithm:
1. Build hierarchy from input data with `hierarchy`
2. Pack sibling circles using `packSiblingsMap` (front-chain algorithm)
3. Compute enclosing circle with `packEnclose`
4. Recursively pack all levels with `pack`

Based on Wang et al.'s "Visualization of Large Hierarchical Data by Circle Packing"
and the D3.js implementation.

declarations.comments: Circle ID for map-based storage
declarations.title: CircleId

declarations.comments: Circle type for geometric operations
declarations.title: Circle

declarations.comments: State for map-based pack algorithm
declarations.title: PackState

declarations.comments: Does circle a enclose circle b (with tolerance)?
declarations.title: enclosesWeak

declarations.comments: Do circles a and b intersect?
declarations.title: intersects

declarations.comments: Position circle c tangent to circles a and b
declarations.title: place

declarations.comments: Pack siblings using map-based front-chain algorithm
declarations.title: packSiblingsMap

declarations.comments: Pack node extends hierarchy with circle coordinates
declarations.title: PackNode

declarations.comments: Configuration for pack layout
declarations.title: PackConfig

declarations.comments: Default pack configuration
declarations.title: defaultPackConfig

declarations.comments: Simple hierarchy node for testing
declarations.title: HierarchyData

declarations.comments: Create a hierarchy from data
declarations.title: hierarchy

declarations.comments:
Apply pack layout to a hierarchy using the map-based algorithm
Implements D3's two-pass algorithm for proper padding
declarations.title: pack

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.Pack

modules.comments:
D3 Partition Layout

Implements the D3 partition layout algorithm for hierarchical data.
Creates rectangular partitions that can be rendered as:
- Icicle charts (vertical stacked rectangles)
- Sunburst charts (radial partitions)

Based on: https://github.com/d3/d3-hierarchy/blob/main/src/partition.js

declarations.comments: Partition node with rectangular coordinates
declarations.title: PartitionNode

declarations.comments: Configuration for partition layout
declarations.title: PartitionConfig

declarations.comments: Default configuration
declarations.title: defaultPartitionConfig

declarations.comments:
Apply partition layout to hierarchical data

Algorithm:
1. Calculate number of layers (n = height + 1)
2. Initialize root coordinates
3. Position all nodes (pre-order traversal)
4. Optional: round coordinates to integers
declarations.title: partition

declarations.comments: Hierarchical data structure (can have children)
declarations.title: HierarchyData

declarations.comments: Convert hierarchical data to PartitionNode (before layout)
declarations.title: hierarchy

declarations.comments:
Convert partition coordinates to sunburst arc path (SVG path string)

Parameters:
- x0, x1: Normalized angles [0,1] representing angular extent around the circle
- y0, y1: Normalized radii [0,1] representing distance from center
- radius: Total radius of the sunburst in pixels

The function handles the special case where the arc spans nearly a full circle
(>99%), which SVG cannot render as a single arc, by splitting it into two
semicircular arcs.

Based on D3's arc generator: https://github.com/d3/d3-shape#arc
declarations.title: sunburstArcPath

declarations.comments:
Flatten PartitionNode tree to array (pre-order traversal)

Returns all nodes in the tree as a flat array, with the root first followed
by all descendants in pre-order traversal order.
declarations.title: flattenPartition

declarations.comments:
Fix parallel layout for sunburst diagrams

Makes children of "parallel" nodes share the parent's angular extent and stack
radially (same angle, different radius) instead of dividing angular space.
This is useful for visualizing simultaneous/overlapping elements.

The predicate function determines which nodes should be treated as "parallel".
For example: `\nodeData -> nodeData.nodeType == "parallel"`
declarations.title: fixParallelLayout

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.Partition

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.Tree

Reingold-Tilford tree layout adapted from the elegant Haskell implementation
Translates binary tree algorithm to n-ary trees (Data.Tree)

declarations.comments:
Configuration for tree layout

The `separation` function controls horizontal spacing between adjacent nodes.
It receives the node data for two adjacent nodes and returns the desired separation.
Default behavior uses `minSeparation` for all nodes.

The `layerScale` function controls vertical spacing between depth levels.
It receives the depth (0 = root) and returns a scale factor for that level.
Default is identity (linear scaling).

Example for "flatter at top" effect:
```purescript
config { layerScale = \depth -> toNumber depth ** 1.5 }
```
declarations.title: TreeConfig

declarations.comments: Default configuration
declarations.title: defaultTreeConfig

declarations.comments:
Configuration with custom layer scaling

Common patterns:
- `\d -> toNumber d ** 1.5` - compressed at top, expanded at bottom
- `\d -> log (toNumber d + 1.0)` - very flat at top
- `\d -> sqrt (toNumber d)` - moderate compression at top
declarations.title: withLayerScale

declarations.comments:
Configuration with fixed layer separation in pixels

When set, layers are spaced by a fixed pixel amount rather than
being normalized to fit within the configured height. This gives
consistent vertical spacing regardless of tree depth.

Example for 60px between layers:
```purescript
withLayerSeparation 60.0 config
```
declarations.title: withLayerSeparation

declarations.comments:
Configuration with custom separation function

Example for radius-based separation:
```purescript
withSeparation (\a b -> (a.radius + b.radius) / 2.0 + 1.0) config
```
declarations.title: withSeparation

declarations.comments:
A contour is a list of offsets at each depth level
Represents the left or right edge of a subtree
declarations.title: Contour

declarations.comments: Contours for a subtree: left edge and right edge at each depth
declarations.title: Contours

declarations.comments:
Tree layout in 3 steps:
1. render: Bottom-up pass computing relative positions (distances from parent)
2. petrify: Top-down pass converting distances to absolute (x,y) coordinates
3. scale: Scale abstract coordinates to pixel coordinates

Uses Tuple annotation to temporarily hold offset values during layout computation
Input must have x, y, depth fields (initial values don't matter, they'll be overwritten)
declarations.title: tree

declarations.comments:
Tree layout with height-based sorting for consistent ordering with Cluster
Use this variant when your tree has height computed and you want sorted children
declarations.title: treeWithSorting

declarations.comments:
Node size for layout calculations
Width affects horizontal spacing (contours track edges, not centers)
Height affects vertical layer spacing (each layer uses max height at that depth)
declarations.title: NodeSize

declarations.comments:
Size-aware tree layout for heterogeneous nodes

Unlike the standard `tree` function which assumes uniform node sizes,
this variant uses a sizing function to query each node's dimensions.

Key differences from standard layout:
- Contours track node edges (center  width/2), not centers
- Layer y-positions based on accumulated max heights, not uniform spacing
- minSeparation becomes pure gap between node edges

Example for a tree with circles and tables:
```purescript
treeSized config nodeSize myTree
  where
  nodeSize node = case node.shape of
    Circle { radius } -> { width: radius * 2.0, height: radius * 2.0 }
    Table { rows } -> { width: 50.0 * numCols, height: 20.0 * numRows }
```
declarations.title: treeSized

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.Tree

modules.comments:
Type-Safe Tree Styles

Bundles tree layout orientation with matching link path generators.
This prevents mismatches like using horizontal beziers with vertical trees.

Usage:
```purescript
-- Get a bundled style with matching link generator
let style = verticalTree { width: 800.0, height: 600.0 }

-- Use the bundled link generator
let pathD = style.linkPath x1 y1 x2 y2

-- Or create a custom style
let custom = customTree myConfig myLinkFn
```

declarations.comments:
A tree style bundles orientation with its matching link path generator.
The orientation is a phantom type that enables type-safe composition.
declarations.title: TreeStyle

declarations.comments:
Type alias for link path generator functions
Takes source (x1, y1) and target (x2, y2), returns SVG path string
declarations.title: LinkPathFn

declarations.comments:
Vertical tree: root at top, children below
Uses vertical bezier curves (control points at midpoint Y)
declarations.title: verticalTree

declarations.comments:
Horizontal tree: root at left, children to the right
Uses horizontal bezier curves (control points at midpoint X)
declarations.title: horizontalTree

declarations.comments:
Radial tree: root at center, children radiate outward
Uses radial bezier curves (control points follow arc)
declarations.title: radialTree

declarations.comments: Get the link path generator from a tree style
declarations.title: linkPath

declarations.comments: Get the orientation from a tree style
declarations.title: orientation

declarations.comments:
Custom tree style with user-provided link generator
Use this when you need a non-standard pairing
declarations.title: customTree

declarations.comments: Tree orientation (used as phantom type marker)
declarations.title: TreeOrientation

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.TreeStyle

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.Treemap

Pure PureScript implementation of D3's treemap layout.
Partitions rectangles to represent hierarchical data with area proportional to value.

declarations.comments:
Node with treemap layout coordinates
Extends ValuedNode with x0, y0, x1, y1 bounds
declarations.title: TreemapNode

declarations.comments:
Tiling function type
Takes parent node and bounds, positions children
declarations.title: TileFunction

declarations.comments: Treemap configuration
declarations.title: TreemapConfig

declarations.comments: Golden ratio for squarify
declarations.title: phi

declarations.comments: Default treemap configuration
declarations.title: defaultTreemapConfig

declarations.comments: Convert ValuedNode to TreemapNode (without positioning)
declarations.title: toTreemapNode

declarations.comments: Main treemap layout function
declarations.title: treemap

declarations.comments: Dice tiling: horizontal partitioning (varies x, constant y)
declarations.title: dice

declarations.comments: Slice tiling: vertical partitioning (constant x, varies y)
declarations.title: slice

declarations.comments:
Slice-dice tiling: alternates between slice and dice at each depth level
Provides a simple alternating pattern
declarations.title: sliceDice

declarations.comments:
Binary tiling: divides space based on splitting the value sum
Simpler approach: split children into two groups, position each group with slice/dice
declarations.title: binary

declarations.comments: Squarify tiling: minimizes aspect ratios (creates more square-like rectangles)
declarations.title: squarify

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.Treemap

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.Types

Pure PureScript implementation of D3 hierarchy types.
Follows D3's conceptual model but uses separate types for each processing phase.

declarations.comments:
Basic hierarchy node after construction
Analogous to D3's Node structure but without layout-specific fields
Type parameter `a` represents the user's data type

Note: This is a data type (not newtype or type synonym) to allow:
1. Recursive definition without cycles
2. Pattern matching
3. Direct field access via record syntax
declarations.title: HierarchyNode

declarations.comments:
Node with computed value (after calling .sum() or .count())
This is a separate type to ensure type safety - can't use value before computing it
declarations.title: ValuedNode

declarations.comments: Helper functions to access node fields
declarations.title: getData

declarations.comments: Helper functions for ValuedNode
declarations.title: getValuedData

declarations.comments: Configuration for hierarchy construction
declarations.title: HierarchyConfig

declarations.comments:
Result of hierarchy construction
Just a type alias for clarity
declarations.title: Hierarchy

declarations.comments:
Result of sum/count operations
Just a type alias for clarity
declarations.title: ValuedHierarchy

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Hierarchy.Types

modules.comments:
Geometric Layout Patterns

Simple, deterministic layout functions for positioning N items within a viewport.
Each function handles all the tedious calculations (aspect ratio, spacing, centering)
and returns an array of points ready to zip with your data.

## Usage

```purescript
import DataViz.Layout.Pattern (grid, phyllotaxis)
import DataViz.Layout.Pattern.Types (viewportWithPadding)

-- Layout 100 items in a grid with 20px padding
let vp = viewportWithPadding 800.0 600.0 20.0
let positions = grid vp 100

-- Zip with your data
let positioned = Array.zipWith (\pos datum -> { x: pos.x, y: pos.y, datum })
                               positions myData
```

declarations.comments:
Lay out N items in a grid, automatically choosing rows/columns
to best fit the viewport's aspect ratio.

Items are centered within the viewport and evenly spaced.
declarations.title: grid

declarations.comments: Grid with a specific target aspect ratio for cells (width/height)
declarations.title: gridWithAspect

declarations.comments: Grid with exact column count specified
declarations.title: gridExact

declarations.comments:
Honeycomb layout - offset alternating rows for hexagonal packing
More compact than a regular grid for circular items.
declarations.title: honeycomb

declarations.comments:
Brick layout - like honeycomb but with rectangular cells
Good for text labels or rectangular items.
declarations.title: brick

declarations.comments:
Phyllotaxis layout - golden angle spiral like sunflower seeds
Produces beautiful, naturally-looking distributions.
Items are placed at increasing distances from center using golden angle.
declarations.title: phyllotaxis

declarations.comments: Archimedean spiral - constant spacing between arms
declarations.title: archimedean

declarations.comments: Fermat spiral - like phyllotaxis but with configurable divergence angle
declarations.title: fermat

declarations.comments: Radial layout - items evenly distributed around a circle
declarations.title: radial

declarations.comments:
Concentric rings - distribute items across multiple rings
Inner rings have fewer items proportional to their circumference.
declarations.title: concentricRings

declarations.comments: Sunburst layout - like concentric rings but with angular sectors
declarations.title: sunburst

declarations.comments: Horizontal line across the viewport
declarations.title: horizontal

declarations.comments: Vertical line down the viewport
declarations.title: vertical

declarations.comments: Diagonal from top-left to bottom-right
declarations.title: diagonal

declarations.comments: Layout along an arbitrary line between two points
declarations.title: along

declarations.comments:
Layered layout - multiple horizontal rows with varying item counts.
Perfect for neural networks, hierarchies, or any row-based visualization.

Takes an array of item counts per layer. Returns flat array of all positions.
Layers are evenly spaced vertically; items within each layer are evenly spaced
horizontally across the full width.

```purescript
-- Neural network: 4 inputs, 8 hidden, 8 hidden, 2 outputs
let positions = layered vp [4, 8, 8, 2]
```
declarations.title: layered

declarations.comments:
Layered layout with items centered in each row.
Unlike `layered`, this centers items using cell-based positioning
(items are centered within evenly-divided cells, not edge-to-edge).

Better for when you want consistent margins at row edges.
declarations.title: layeredCentered

CSV parsing utilities for Sankey diagram data.
Parses CSV files with source,target,value format.

Parse CSV string into array of LinkCSVRow

Example:

  B,C,5

declarations.comments: Parse a single CSV line into LinkCSVRow
declarations.title: parseLine

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Sankey.CSV

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Sankey.Compute

Pure PureScript implementation of Sankey diagram layout computation.
Uses State monad to thread graph model through all layout functions.
Starts with Array SankeyLinkInput and generates nodes dynamically.

Reference: https://github.com/d3/d3-sankey (ISC License)

declarations.comments:
Main entry point: Compute Sankey layout with default configuration
Takes array of link inputs with named nodes (from CSV parsing)
declarations.title: computeLayout

declarations.comments:
Compute Sankey layout with custom configuration
This is the main algorithm using State monad to thread the graph model
declarations.title: computeLayoutWithConfig

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Sankey.Compute

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Sankey.ComputeWithSteps

Version of Sankey layout that captures intermediate states at each iteration.
Uses the same algorithm as Compute.purs but captures states after each
relaxation iteration for debugging and visual comparison.

declarations.comments:
Compute Sankey layout with intermediate steps captured
Runs the full D3-style algorithm but captures state after each relaxation iteration
declarations.title: computeLayoutWithSteps

modules.name: DataViz.Layout.Sankey.ComputeWithSteps

modules.comments:
DataViz.Layout.Sankey.Path

SVG path generation for Sankey link curves.
Generates the characteristic curved ribbons for flow visualization.

declarations.comments: Helper to find node by ID
declarations.title: findNode

declarations.comments:
Generate SVG path data for a Sankey link
Creates a cubic bezier curve ribbon from source to target
This draws a filled area (not just a stroke) by creating a closed path
declarations.title: generateLinkPath

declarations.comments:
Alternative: Generate horizontal link path (straight lines)
Useful for debugging or different visual styles
declarations.title: generateStraightPath

that integrate naturally with the phantom type system.

Internal node representation after layout computation
This has all computed properties needed for rendering

declarations.comments:
Graph model for State monad - contains all intermediate computation state
SankeyGraphModel is created by folding rows of CSV

Get the inner ring for a final state (double circle effect)

The arc radius is computed from the distance between start and control points

A simple horizontal arrow pointing right

Generate SVG path for an arrowhead at the end of a transition

Computed path for a transition arrow
Uses quadratic bezier for curved arrows
